X 182 116 222
Having sent my family home
to England I beganstarted mythe on my last
journey from Cape Town on
in the beginning of June 1852 which
This journey extended from the Southern
Extremity of the continent to
St Paul di LoandoLuanda onthe capital of Angola
on the West coast and thence
accross the South central Africa
in an oblique direction to
QuilimaneQuelimane in Eastern Africa
I proceeded in the usual
conveyance of the country,
the heavy lumbering Cape
waggon drawn by ten oxen
and was accompanied by
two Christian Bechuanas from Kuruman
who than whom I never saw
better servants anywhere - Two
Bakuena men and two
little ^ young girls who having come
as nurses with our children
to the Cape were returning
to their home at Kolobeng
Waggon travelling in Africa
has been so often described
that I need say no more than
it is that waggon this life ^ it is is just
an prolonged system of pic-
-nicing - excellent for the
health and agreeable to those
who are not over fastidious
183 223
about trifles and ^ who delight in ^ being the
in the open air -

Our route on leavingto the North the
Cape lay near the centre of the
Cone into which constitutes
the promontory of the Cape, If
we suppose this cone to be
divided into three zones or longitudinal bands, we find
each presenting distinct
peculiarities of climate,
physical appearance and
population These are more
marked beyond thanan within
the Colony - At some points
too, one district seems to be
continued intoin and merge into
the other, but the general
dissimilarity warrants the
division as an aid to
memory - The Eastern zone
is often furnished ^ with mountainouss, well
wooded bywith ^ evergreen succulent trees on which
neither fire
nor droughts can
have the smallest effect
Strelieyt Strelitzia ( Zamias horrida - portulacaria afra
Schotia speciosa, Euphorbias & Aloes arborescens)
and the ^ seaboard gorges with gigantic
timber - It is also ^ comparatively well
watered with streams and
flowing rivers - The annual
supply of rain is considerable
and the inhabitants (Caffres or ZulasZulus) are
tall muscular and well
made. They are shrewd
energetic and brave and
altogether they merit the character given
184 224
them by military authorities of
being "magnificent savages"
Their splendid physical development
and form of skull shewshow that but for the
black skin they would take rank ^ among the foremost
Europeans

The zone again which
embraces the centre of the
continent can scarcely be
called hilly for it consists
of low hills and extensive
& slightly undulating plains
The latter predominate
and there are no lofty mountains
There are few fountains
and fewer flowing streams
Rains areis far from abundant
and droughts may be expected
every few years - Without
artificial irrigation no European
grain can be raised, and
the inhabitants (Bechuanas)
though evidently of one stock
originally with those on the
already mentioned ^ East side of the continent
and closely resembling them
in being an agricultural as
well as a pastoral people
are a comparatively timid
race, and inferior to the
Kaffirs Caffres in physical development

The Western zone is still
more level than the middle
one, being rugged only near
185 225
The coast - It includes the
great plain called the Kalahari
desert which is remarkable
for little water and very
considerable vegetation

p.seg:
The reason why so
little rain falls on this
extensive plain probably is
this - The prevailing winds
of most of the ^ Interior country are
Easterly with a little Southing
The moisture taken up by
the atmosphere from the
Indian Ocean is always
deposited on the Eastern
hilly slope and when the
moving mass of air the atmosphere
reaches its greatest elevation
it is then on the verge of
the great valley or as
it is in the case of the Kalahari the
great heated inland plains
There meeting with the rarified
air of that hot hot dry
surface the ascending heat
gives it greater capacity
for retaining all its
remaining humidity and
few showers can be given
to the middle & Western lands
in consequence of the
increased hygrometric power

p.del:
The large vegetation
of the Kalahari so different

p.seg:
This is the same phenomenon
on a gigantic scale which
takes place on Table mountain
in what is called the spreading
of the table cloth - The South
East wind causes a mass
of air equal to the diameter
of the mountain lsuddenly
to ascend at least a thousand
feet - The rarification produced
by altitude ^ & cold causes the immediate
formation of a cloud on the
summit, successive masses
of air cause the continual
formation of clouds but
the summit top of the vapoury
mass or "Table cloth" is level
and seemingly motionless
on the lee side however the
thick volumes of vapour
curl over and descend but
when they reach the point
below where greater density
has greater capacity for
carrying water They entirely
disappear

Now if instead of a
hollow on the lee side of
Table mountain we had
a heated plain the clouds
which curl over and disappear
as they do now might deposit
some moisture there
but the heat would impart
187 227
impart the increased capacity
it now recievesreceives at the lower
level and instead of an
extended country with a
flora of the Disa grandiflora,
gladiolus, & rushes and lichens
we should have the hardy grassy
vegetation of the Kalahari

div.p:
Why there should be
so much vegetation
on the Kalahari may be explained
by the geological formation
of the country - There is aseems
to be a rim or fringe of ancient
rocks all round the great
central valley which generally
dip into an ancient basin
wh the bottom of which is
composed of the most
ancient Silurian rocks
This basin has been
burst through and filled
up in many parts by
eruptive traps & Breccias
which often bear in
their substances ^ angular fragments
of the more ancient rocks
as shewnshown in the fossils
they contain - Now though
large areas have been
so dislocated that but
little trace of the original
valley formation appears
it is highly probable that
188 228
it still holds true of most of the
country and as the strata
on the slopes where most
of the rain falls dip in towards
the centre they probably guide
water beneath plains but
ill supplied with moisture
from the clouds - The
phenomenon of stagnant
fountains becoming by
a new outlet never
failing streams may be
confirmatory of the same
view. And it is not
beyond the bounds of
probability too that the
wonderful river system
in the North which if
the native information
be correct influencescauses
the rise of the springs
called at N Matlomaganyana
(the links) extends its
fertilising influence
beneath the plains of the
Kalahari

The peculiar formation
of the country explains why
there is & should be such a
difference ofin the vegetation
between the ^ 20° 30° parallels of latitude in central of Australia
and the same latitudes in
South Africa - This holds
true of The want of
vegetation is as true
189 2289
of some parts in the centre
of South America of the
same Latitudes as of Australia
And it opens the difference
holds out a high degree
of probability for the
success of Artesian
wells in extensive tracts
now unpeopled solely
on account of want of
water - We thus coincan
elements of future greatness
which we cannot hope
for in Australia or ChiliChile
and aAs the central parts
of the Cape Colony are daily
becoming of higher value
offering to honest industry
a fair renumeration
for capital besides a
climate unequalled in
salubrity for consumptive
patients - I should un-
hesitatingly recommend
any farmer at all afraid
of that complaint to
try the Colony in preference
to Madeira With the
means of education already
possessed and the onward
and upward movement
of the Cape population he
need entertain no appre-
hensions of his family
sinking into barbarism

190 230
The route we at this time
followed ran along the middle
andor skirted the Western zone
before alluded to, untilluntil we
reached the latitude of Lake
Ngami where a totally
different country begins
While in the Colony we passed
through districts inhabited
by the descendants of the Dutch &
French refugees from religious
persecution - Those living
near the Capital differ but
little from the middle classes
in English rural counties
and excel in public spirit
and general intelligence
while those situated far from
the centres of civilization
are less informed but are
a body of frugal, industrious,
and hospitable peasantry-
A most efficient system
of public instruction was
established in the time
of Governor Sir George Napier
on a plan drawn up in
a great measure by that
accomplished philosopher
Sir John Herschel - the
system had to contend with
less sectarian rancour than
elsewhere - Indeed untilluntil quite
recently such rancour
except in a mild form was unknown
191 121231
The population here
described ought
not and probably
would not
be confounded
with some Boer
who fled from
British rule
on account
of the emancipation
of their Hottentot
slaves Bbut as every now and then
QuQuery some Rip Van Getze Winkle starts
forth at the Cape to justify in
the public prints the deeds
of blood and slavehunting
in the far Interior, it is not to
be wondered at if the whole
race is held in low estimation
by those who know not
the real composition of the
Cape community -

Population among the Boers
increases rapidly - They marry
soon - have children late
and are seldom sterile - I once
met a worthy matron whose
husband thought it right to
imitate ^ the conduct of Abraham while
Sarah was barren; she evidently
agreed in the propriety of the
measure for she was pleased
to hear the children ^ by a mother of what
has been though an inferior
race, ^ and they address her as their
mother - Orphans are never
left allowed to remain long
destitute and instances are
perpetually seenfrequent in which a
the tender hearted farmer has
adopted a fatherless child
and will when it comescame of
age ^ has portioned it as his own -
ᒥTwo Two centuries of the South
African climate has not had
192 232
much effect upon the ^ physical condition of the Boers - race - They
are a shade darker than Europeans
or rather ruddier, than Europeans
on the body - and Areare never cadaverous
looking as descendants of
Europeans are said to be
elsewhere - There is a tendency
to the development of steatopygasteatopygia
so characteristic of Arabs &
other African tribes, and it
is probable that they will getin
colour and strong robust
forms, of the Interior boersBoers
will become what the
learned imagine those of
our progenitors Adam and Eve
to have been -

The parts of the Colony through
which we passed were
of sterile aspect and as the
time of our passing was being
the winter after a severe drought
^ so severe
many farmers
had lost two
thirds of their
stock the landscape was uninviting,
the hills, destitute of trees, were
of a dark brown colour
and the scanty vegetation
on the plains made me
feel this ^ that it deserved the name of
desert more than ^ the Kalahari

193 233
When first taken possession of,
these parts are said to have been
covered with a coating of grass
but that has disappeared with
the antelopes which fed upon
it and a crop of Mesembryanthe--mums
and crassulas occupyies its place - It is
curious to observe how in
nature, organismszations the most
dissimilar are mutually dependant
^ upon Each other --- ^ for their perpetuallytion ^ - Here the
grasses were dependantdependent for
dissemination on the grass
feeding animals which scattered
the seeds - When by the death
of the antelopes no fresh sowing
was made the African droughts
proved too much for this form
of vegetation But even this
contingency was foreseen
by the Omniscient One for as
we may now observe in the
Kalahari desert another family
of plants (Mesembryanthemums) stood ready
to neutralize the aridity which
must otherwise have followed -
This family of plants possesses a seed
vessels which remains firmly
shut on itstheir contents while the
soil is hot and dry and
thus preserves the vegetative
power intact during the
highest heat of the Torrid
sun, But when rain falls
194 234
the seed vessels openss and shedss
their its contents just when there is
the greatest probability of its their
vegetating - In other plants
heat & drought cause the
seed vessels to burst
and shed their charge

One of this family his edible
(Mesembryanthemum edule)
another possesses a tuberous
root which may be eaten raw
and all are furnished with
thick fleshy leaves having
pores capable of imbibing and
retaining moisture from the
most unlikely atmosphere
and soil, so that if a leaf
is broken during a period
of the greatest drought it shewsshows
abundant circulating sap -
The plants of this species are
found much farther North
but the great abundance of the
grasses prevents them from
making any shewshow - There
however they stand ready to
fill up any gap which may
occur in the present prevailing
vegetation, and should the grasses
disappear animal life would
not necessarily be destroyed
because a reserve supply an equivalent to
^ a fresh an act of creative power
has been provided

195 125235
As this new vegetation is
better adapted for sheep and goats
in a dry country than grass the
boersBoers supplement the latter by
imitating the process by which
graminivorous antelopes have
so abundantly disseminated the
seed - A few waggon loads
of Mesembryanthemum plants
in seed are brought to a
farm covered with a scanty
crop of course grass, and
placed on a spot to which
the sheep have access in the
evenings - As they eat a little
every night the seeds are
dropped over the farm grazing
grounds in this simple way
with a regularity with a regularity
which could not be matched
except by at the cost of an immense amount
of labour - The place ^ thus becomes
in the course of a few years
as was intended a sheep farm
196 236
As already mentioned some
plants of this family are
furnished with an additional
contrivance for withstanding
droughts vizvidelicet - oblong tubers
which buried deep enough
beneath the soil for complete
protection from the scorching
sun, serve as reservoirs
of sap and nutriment during
those rainless periods which
recur perpetually in even the
most favoured spots of Africa
I have adverted to this peculiarity
as often seen in the vegetation
of the Desert and though rather
out of place it may be
well in noticing a clever
imitation of one process in
nature by the Cape farmer to
mentionsuggest another for their
consideration - When the
country beyond South LatLatitude 18°
abounds aboundants in three varieties
ink line across page
of grape bearing vines, and
one of these is furnished with
oblong tubers every three or four
inches along the horizontal
root - They resemble closely
those of the asparagus - and
This increase of power to
withstand the effects of climate
might prove of value in those
more arid parts of the Cape Colony for grapes being
well known asto be an excellent
197 237
restorative in the debility produced
by heat - ᒥby engrafting or
by some of those curious
manipulations ˄ which we read of
in books of gardening a
variety might be secured better
adapted to the country than
the foreign vines from which
at present cultivated - The
Americans find that some
of their native vines yield
wines superior to those made
from the very best imported
vines from France and
Portugal - What a boon a
vine of the sort contemplated
would have been to a
Rhenish missionary I met
at a part in the West of the
colony called Ebenezer
whose children had never
seen flowers though old
enough to talk about them -

The slow pace at which
we wound our way through
the Colony made almost
any subject interesting - The
attention is attracted to the names
of different places because
they indicated the former
existence of Buffaloes, Elands
and Elephants which are now
to be found only hundreds of
miles beyond - A few blesbok
198 128 238
Wildebeests
Bluebucks
Steinbucks
and the Ostrich (Struthio )
continue like the Bushmen to
hold a precarious existence
when all the rest are gone
The Elephant the most sagacious
flees the sound of fire arms
first, The gnu and ostrich
the most wary and the most
stupid last The first emigrants
found the Hottentots in possession
of prodigious herds of fine
cattle but no horses, asses
or camels - The original cattle
which may still be seen in
some parts of the frontier
must have been brought
South from the North North
East for from this point
the natives universally ascribe
their original migration -
They brought cattle sheep,
goats and dogs - Why not
the horse the delight of savage
hordes? Horses thrive well
in the Cape Colony when
Qu:Query omit imported from ships - Naturalists
point out certain mountain
ranges as limiting the range
of certain classes of animals
but there is no Cordillera in
Africa to answer that purpose
199 239
There being no visible barriers
between the North Eastern
Arabs and the the Bechuana and
Hottentot tribes to prevent the
different hordes as they felt
their way Southwards to ˄ from indulgeing
their taste for the possession
of this noble animal I am
led to notice an invisible one
barrier more insurmountable than
mountain ranges, but which
is not opposed to the Southern
progress of cattle goats and
sheep - The Tsetse would
prove a barrier only untilluntil
they knew its well defined
habitat, but the disease
known as horse sickness
(peripneumonia) exists in
such virulence over
nearly seven degrees of
latitude that no precaution
would be sufficient to save
theses animals - The horse
is so amenable to this disease
that only by great care in
stabling can a horse be kept
anywhere between 20º S -South & 27º
during the months time between
December and April - The winter
beginning in the latter month
is the only period in which
Englishmen can hunt on
horseback and they are in
danger of losing all their studs
some months before December
200 130 240
To this disease the horse is
especially liable and it is almost
always fatal - One attack however
seems to secure immunity
from anothera second or rather
it proves thatwould seem as if nothing but
shooting him willwould kill the
horse which gets over it -
Cattle too it is true are subject
to it but only at intervals of
a few sometimes many years
but it never makes a
clean sweep of the ˄ whole cattle of
a village as it would do
in a troop of fifty horses
This barrier then seems to
explain the absence of the
horse among the Hottentots
though it is not opposed to
the southern migration of
cattle sheep and goats

When the flesh of animals
which die of this disease is
eaten it causes a malignant
carbuncle which when it
appears over any important
organ proves rapidly fatal
It is more especially dangerous
over the pit of the stomach
The virus ˄ in the flesh of the animal is neither destroyed
by boiling nor roasting - It
had happened in The effects of the
poison have
been experienced by missionaries
even who had eaten properly
cooked food the flesh of
201 131241
sheep really but not visibly
affected by the disease - This
fact of which we have had
innumerable examples shewsshows
the superiority of experiments
on a large scale to those of an
of an acute and able physiologists
and Chemist in histhe laboratory
with dogs as the for a
well known physician
Complete DrDoctor ―-- of Paris after
careful investigation thought
the virus in such cases to be
completely neutralised by
boiling

This disease attacks wild
animals too - During our residence
at Chonuane great numbers
of Tolos or Khoodoos were
attracted to the gardens of the
Bakwains abandoned at
the usual period of harvest
because there was no prospect
of the corn (Caffre sorghum
bearing that year - The
Khoodoo is remarkably fond
of the green stalks of this
kind of millet - Free feeding
produced that state ˄ of fatness favourable
for the development of the
disease viz -videlicet fatnand no fewer
than twenty five died on the
hill opposite our house - Great
numbers of Wildebeests and
202 242
zebras perished from the same
cause - but the mortality
produced no sensible diminution
in the numbers of the game, noany more than
the deaths of many who
73 [persisted in spite of every
remonstrance to eat ˄ in eating the dead
meat caused any dsensible
decrease in the strength of
the tribe - In In thethe case of horses
not one would have been left -

The farms of the Boers con-
sist consist generally of a small patch
of cultivated land in the midst
of some miles of pasturage
They are thus less an agricultural
than ˄ a pastoral people - Each
farm must have its fountain
and where no such supply of
water exists the Government
lands are unsaleable - An acre
in England is thus oftmore valuable
than a ˄ square mile in Africa - But
the country is prosperous and
capable of great improvement
The industry of the Boers bodes
well for the future formation
of dams and tanks and greater
fruitfulness -

203 243
As cattle and sheep farmers the
colonists are very successful
Increasingly ˄ Llarge quantities of wool are
produced annually and the
value of Colonial farms
increases year by year - But
the system requires that with
the increase of the population
there should be an extension
of territory - Wide as the country
is and thinly inhabited, the
farmers feel it to be too smalllimited
and gradually spread to the
North - This movement proves
prejudicial to the country behind
for industrylabour which would
be directed to the improvement
of the Colony is withdrawn
and expended in a mode of
life little adapted for the exercise
of industrial habits - That however
does not much concern the rest
of mankind - Nor does it seem
much of an evil for men who cultivate
the soil to claim a right to
appropriate lands which other
men only hunt over provided
some com-
pensation for
the loss of
sustenance
be awarded The original
idea of a title seems to have
been ˄ that "subduing" or cultivationng
gave that right - But this
rather Chartist principle
must be recievedreceived with limitations
for its recognition in England
would lead to the seizure of
all our broad ancestral acres
204 244
by those who are willing to
cultivate them - And in the
case under consideration
the encroachments lead at
once to less land being put
under the plowugh than is
subjected to the native hoe
for it is an undisputed
fact that the CaffresKaffirs ˄ BasutusBasutos cultivate
largely - , ˄ and undersell our farmers
wherever they have a fair
field and no favour, - And
anthe insignificant tribe of
BasutasBasutos ˄ for instance actually raise
more grain annually than
the whole Eastern Province
for which we ˄ have expended
millions of Pounds and
thousands of lives - Would it
not be better to
furnish the
real agriculturists
with ploughs
than attempt
to exterminate
them which
can only be
effected at
a cost which
will make
our Eastern
Province the
dearest land
in the world

205 245 135
Before we came to the Orange
river we saw the last portion
of a migration of springbucks
(Gazelle Euchore) or Tsépe) They
come from the great Kalahari
Desert and when seen after
first crossing the Colonial
boundary are said often
to numberExceed forty thousand, ˄ in number
I cannot give an estimate
for they appear in vast
numbers expanses of country
and make a quivering motion
as they feed & move and toss
their graceful antlers, They
feed chiefly on grass and
as they come ˄ from the North about
the time when the grass most
abounds it cannot be want
of food that prompts the
movement - Nor is it want-
ing water for this antelope
is one of the most abstemious
Their nature prompts them to
seek, for their haunts, level
plains with short grass so
as to be able to watch the approach
of an enemy - The Bakalahari
take advantage of this feeling
and burn off large patches
of grass - not only to attract the
game by the newly spring crop
when it comes but also
to form bare spots for the springbuks
